job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Turlock, CA
pros: Awesome teamwork among nurses, charge nurses, cNA’s , MD’s and PT/OT. the patients are rough sometimes but it’s manageable with the right staff .
cons: Management could be more understanding, especially if unit is understaffed. Like not focus on petty issues like the wrong color undershirt or a sweater over the uniform… could try focusing on important issues such as the decrease in patient’s safety when frequently working understaffed.

pros: Got good experience working here, teamwork.
cons: doesn't follow ratios, missing breaks/lunches

pros: The people that you work with make it so fun to work here even when it’s a tough time. They recently have been recognizing the staff for their hard work again and that has to do with the CEO implementing the “Bring your Heart to work” award with boosts morale.
cons: 1. Pay for all that we do and see is not enough. The stress especially during what happened when COVID-19 was at its highest really took a toll on staffing. 2. Vacation time is really good but you can never use it when you want unless someone quits, gets fired or goes away on medical leave and doesn’t return. 3. Work and life balance doesn’t happen 4. If you want to ask for a day off one day 2 weeks or 1 month or more in advance you won’t get get because of policy. 5. There are people in certain Departments that frown on you because of your job, especially if you are in EVS…don’t only take my word for it. 6. The food has gotten worse in quality and this is from multiple sources in a couple departments.

job_title: PCT Patient Care Tech in Turlock, CA
pros: Great 4 days off 3 days on
cons: Tired too much work nights

pros: Great teamwork and nurse managers.
cons: Little support from management and directors.

job_title: Emergency Department Technician in Turlock, CA
pros: Staff and Colleagues were on par.
cons: Management was constantly changing, near leadership.

pros:
I’ve worked at Emanuel for several years as a CNA and for a year as an RN. I have been to every floor and every department as both a CNA and an RN. I have gotten to know all of the staff members, and they’re all fairly nice, with a few exceptions, but that’s no different from any hospital I’d assume.
This is a great place if your local to the area and don’t want to commute or if you’re trying to get your foot in the door in the medical field. Although, Memorial Medical Center is one city over, and far better from what I’ve been told.
Great place to start off as a new RN and gain experience, seems like a lot of people from the Bay Area and Sacramento area do exactly that. They’ll come and stay for 6 months to a year, and then move out to a bigger and better hospital.
cons: Management really does not care abt you, or your needs as an employee. No breaks, sometimes no lunches. Management genuinely will not do anything abt hiring more staff, or care abt increasing pay for there employees to help retain them. With inflation at roughly 9%, and a mediocre union bid to increase annual pay by 4% per year for 4 years is a slap to the face. Even as a CNA, there were newer CNA hires with no experience coming in that were getting paid a higher base salary than I was, when I had been there for several years. As an RN, staffing no ratios are horrible. Pre-pandemic we’d be 4:1 if they’re tele pts, and 5:1 otherwise. Now, we are 5:1 on a good day, and sometimes at 6:1 and even 7:1 depending on how short we are for the day. To combat this they offer Triple Agency pay and Bonuses, but even then it’s seldom, and still not enough of a boost to make it worthwhile. Any time you pick up past the 40 hours, taxes on your income are increased, so yes they’re offering more money but it ends up getting taken out by taxes. A solution: just offer your employees a higher base pay, rather than hiring more travel nurses. Fix the long term issue, not by hiring more travel RNs, but by increasing base pay. This’ll retain more employees, and then hire more nurses. Hope this helped.

pros: community based nursing with hard working people.
cons: it was purchased by large corporation

pros: flexible hours, great management, good benefits
cons: Payroll is a third party so hard to get the information needed. low pay rate

review_title: Great experience just not enough staff
pros: Great place for learning if your a new nurse
cons: Never have enough staff everday there is a staffing shortage but yet make new policies on top of a "staffing shortage".

pros: - great STEMI care, - Commitees that are RN driven to speak their voice and review change (not that it is always listened to)
cons: - poor care from incompetent nurses, - RN training facility because or low pay - worry more about making money than exceptional care, - all about proper paperwork to CYA, - expensive poor quality medical insurance for employees, - poor electronic charting setup, mostly alpaperwork with double charting electronically

review_title: Still being here after several years speaks volumes.
pros: The people and community have kept me here .  I love the sense of family and warmth I get from being a part of a team that cares.
cons: The only challenges I face here is more and more people have less and less of a work ethic.  The work culture is gradually changing over the years.

pros: I interviewed and was hired very quickly. I had excellent employees.
cons: Asked to be a director of a unit but never officially given the title yet expected to do the job, held responsible for any problems but never received the promised promotion. People in general not given the resources to succeed.

review_title: Best Hospital, Best People, Best Leadership
job_title: Patient Safety Officer in Turlock, CA
pros: The leadership is extraordinarily driven for excellence in patient care - always. Committed to bringing high quality services to a community hospital rather than travel to large metro region hospitals.
cons: Honestly, not sure there are negatives to report. A most enjoyable place to work! Just FYI, the current CEO is Lani Dickinson...Phenomenal!

pros: Management works well with your schedule. Night shift runs short staff frequently but manage with good team work.
cons: The pay is the lowest in the Central Valley. The benefits can be better as well. If these two were improved, staff would stay. Staff do not stay long and the staff are very green, which is not safe.

pros: It's a good friendly place to work at. You are on the move with doing your job. Once your done there isn't much to do and you can just pretty much lay back. That's something I don't like.
cons: They are cheap on giving raises. They rather spend it on unnecessary things then take care of there employees.

pros: It is close by and the pay is not bad.they used to have pretty good benefits and they used to help with school if related to medical field.
cons: Its all about money to the new owners "The Tenent corporation" this used to be a non profit hospital.

pros: The benefits are good, and I like the people I work with.
